discourse_list.title: MIP6 Collateral Onboarding Application: Emerging Markets Green Opportunity: Financing for ATD Combustors\xe2\x80\x99 Egyptian Power Plant Efficiency Projects

content.content: MIP6 Collateral Onboarding Application: Emerging Markets Green Opportunity: Financing for ATD Combustors’ Egyptian Power Plant Efficiency Projects  Who is the interested party for this collateral application?  Issuer: ATD Combustors, a UAE limited liability company (ATDC) Advisor to ATDC: Oasis Pro Markets LLC (together with its affiliates, Oasis Pro)  Provide a brief high-level overview of the project, with a focus on the applying collateral token.  Real World Asset Proposed: Note(s) secured by the Security Guarantor and Collateral. The Note(s) will be full recourse obligations to ATDC and the Security Guarantor. This MIP6 is submitted by Oasis Pro, as advisor, to propose a new asset for the Real World Asset Core Unit involving the Note(s) issued by ATDC. Subsequent to the issuance of the Bonds and to facilitate liquidity and market-based valuation, the Bonds, as well as equity of the Company, could be listed on Oasis Pro’s alternative trading system. While this MIP6 is for a $35mm financing, the opportunity to fund additional green projects in Egypt and other countries in the Middle East could be as much as $500mm - $1bn. Collateral: ATDC will provide collateral guarantee of: Cashflows/receivables under existing Services Agreement between ATDC and the Egyptian Electricity Holding Company (EEHC), a company representing the Egyptian Ministry of Electricity and Renewable Energy, entered into in August 2016, and a pledged cash account in ADGM. Under this agreement, ATDC receives a share of the plant’s cost savings, and such USD savings will be deposited into a pledged ADGM cash account until disbursement (as specified or limited in the final documentation). Investor in Bonds for the benefit of MakerDAO: a legal entity organized in Abu Dhabi Global Markets (ADGM entity).  Provide a brief history of the project.  This MIP6 is submitted by Oasis Pro, as advisor, to propose a new asset for the Real World Asset Core Unit involving the Note(s) issued by ATDC. Subsequent to the issuance of the Bonds and to facilitate liquidity and market-based valuation, the Bonds, as well as equity of the Company, could be listed on Oasis Pro’s alternative trading system. While this MIP6 is for a $35mm financing, the opportunity to fund additional green projects in Egypt and other countries in the Middle East could be as much as $500mm - $1bn. Established in 2014, ATDC is registered in the UAE and has operations in Egypt and the UAE. ATDC is engaged in the development of state-of-the-art clean technology for power generation, the execution of energy savings and performance enhancing projects to reduce energy costs. ATDC’s application-based R&D and combustion technology expertise are utilized to design and develop conventional, hybrid and renewable customized solutions for power generation. ATDC also provides energy optimization of plant performance, the operation and maintenance of sustainable solutions for power generation and energy and water savings for industrial facilities, buildings, and large venues. In the Middle East, unlike much of Europe and the U.S., the use of natural gas and transition to greenfield solar and wind farms is not always an available option to reduce carbon emissions. ATDC is a leading provider in the Middle East of green carbon-reducing strategies and technologies that improve the efficiency of existing power plant systems, thereby both reducing the overall fuel usage and generating of carbon credits. In its pilot project, ATDC has been successful in increasing the fuel efficiency of the Walidia power plant. The Al-Walidia power plant in Egypt is a performing example of ATDC’s implementation of its fuel-reducing technology and the first such improvement project in Egypt. ATDC has a 12-year agreement with EEHC to provide services in respect of the Al-Walidia power plant. ATDC has completed performance on the first four years of the 12-year term agreed upon by ATDC and EEHC. The project has three key objectives: a. Reduce fuel cost by creating fuel efficiencies —The project has reduced fuel cost by 5.2% to date. b. Generate carbon credits through a reduction in fuel usage — The fuel reduction at the Al-Walidia power plant produces approximately 130,000 tons per annum in carbon credits. c. Reduce overall plant maintenance cost — The efficiencies implemented by ATDC have to date resulted in reducing the operation and maintenance cost by 0.71 cents/kWh. Because of the initial success of this project, the Egyptian authorities have offered to join ATDC in its effort via a partnership agreement to benefit six additional power stations. ATDC is also expected to finance and execute power plants rehabilitation, improve fuel savings and plant efficiency, reduce electricity consumption and supervise O&M teams. Furthermore, ATDC has invested in the development of a new technology called “T-fire Combustor”. ATDC is in the process of establishing the first design of the combustor for AVON engines. This combustor will lower nitric oxide emissions as well as improve the reliability / availably and extend the life of the combustor/engine and is adaptable with various types of engines.  Link the whitepaper, documentation portals, and source code for the system(s) that interact with the proposed collateral, and all relevant Ethereum addresses. If the system is complex, schematic(s) are especially appreciated.  https://dailynewsegypt.com/2018/04/03/nomp-signs-cooperation-protocol-atd-maintenance-power-plants/    Enterprise    Egypt lays out 2030 renewable energy targets | Enterprise The Sisi administration wants to grow renewable energy capacity to cover 42% of the country’s electricity needs by 2030, Oil Minister Tarek El Molla announced at the UN’s COP26 climate summit in Glasgow on Thursday, according to a ministry statement....         atd-ae.com   Energy Industry Solutions ATD - simple life solutions        oecd.org    Key_Messages_EMnet_Green_Economy_EnergyTransitionEmergingMarkets.pdf 1328.94 KB      ATDC will use the proceeds of the Note(s) to primarily to refinance an existing bank loan used for its capital expenditure obligations under the Services Agreement to improve the Al-Walidia plant, additional Egyptian efficiency projects and new product development. In addition to making the Al Walidia plant more energy efficient, ATDC will integrate a solar thermal system at the plant. While this MIP6 is for a $35mm financing, the opportunity to fund additional green projects in Egypt and other countries in the Middle East could be as much as $500mm - $1bn.  Link any available audits of the project. Both procedural and smart contract focused audits.  Baker Tilly has produced a report valuing the Walidia Power Plant Project. This report is available confidentially.  Link to any active communities relating to your project.  The Case for Green Money: The case for Clean Money  How is the applying collateral type currently used?  ATDC has a 12-year agreement with EEHC to provide services in respect of the Al-Walidia power plant. ATDC has completed performance on the first four years of the 12-year term agreed upon by ATDC and EEHC. The investment requested in this MIP is not only backed by the revenue from ATDC’s pilot Egyptian energy project, but also the full and unconditional guarantee of Al Hail, the investment vehicle, of UAE royal family member, used to invest in emerging growth areas, such as green technologies. Al Hail has significant holdings in UAE real estate, banking and technology companies like ATDC. Based on audited financial statements, Al Hail had approximately 360mm AED cash (USD 98mm) and 1,820mm AED (USD 500mm) as of 9/30/2021.  Does one organization bear legal responsibility for the collateral? What jurisdiction does that organization reside in?  The collateral and support for the Notes will be the cashflows/receivables under the existing Services Agreement between ATDC and the EEHC and the full and unconditional guarantee by Al Hail (the family office of a royal family member). The Notes will have full recourse to ATDC and Al Hail will guarantee all of ATDC’s obligations under the Notes. Both ATDC and Al Hail are domiciled in the UAE.  Where does exchange for the asset occur?  It is contemplated that the Notes will be purchased by a legal entity organized in the Abu Dhabi Global Markets for the benefit of the MakerDao ecosystem.  (Optional) Has your project obtained any legal opinions or memoranda regarding the regulatory standing of the token or an explanation of the same from the perspective of any jurisdiction? If so, those materials should be provided for community review.  The preliminary structure has been vetted by Latham & Watkins, but any additional written advice may be provided as necessary upon approval of this MIP6.  (Optional) Describe whether there are any regulatory registrations for the token and provide related documentation (including an explanation of any past or existing interactions with any regulatory authorities, regardless of jurisdiction), if applicable.  As stated in 10 above, a preliminary structure was established, but further legal and regulatory due diligence will be conducted after the approval of this MIP 6.  (Optional) List any possible oracle data sources for the proposed Collateral type.  TBD.  (Optional) List any parties interested in taking part in liquidations for the proposed Collateral type.  N/A  Provide (a) proposed legal structure for transaction, including: type of legal entities, (offshore/onshore, form (trust, corporate, other)) and jurisdiction(s) of legal entities, and (b) likely funds flow (DAI => Fiat => DAI).  Legal documentation and the set up any new ADGM or other legal entity to invest in the Bonds, will be handled by Latham & Watkins, as counsel to Oasis Pro, who is an advisor to India Power in connection with this financing. MakerDAO’s legal counsel, North Lakes Legal PLLC, would review such documentation and perform any legal assessments deemed necessary. India Power will be responsible for the legal fees incurred in executing this transaction. Note, while this MIP6 contemplates an ADGM entity as the investor of record for the Bonds, after further assessment of tax, regulatory and other legal issues, it may be determined that the investor of record should be domiciled in another jurisdiction. In the unlikely event of an emergency shutdown occurring with the MakerDAO community, it shall be possible to move the tokens to a holder (subject to KYC and AML checks) in order to transfer and redeem the underlying value. It is anticipated that North Lakes Legal will perform the necessary assessments for this MIP, including, but not limited to: (1) reviewing and negotiating any legal documentation evidencing the Notes, any guarantee and any collateral granted to secure the Notes obligations, as well as any ancillary or supplemental documentation, (2) reviewing security interest documents and advice relating to perfection thereof in Egypt and (3) reviewing any regulatory advice obtained in connection with this transaction. Internationally-recognized legal counsel may be engaged to advise for the benefit of MakerDao. The following diagram illustrates the proposed structure:   Provide details on the organizational structure of the interested party, beneficial ownership, governance/control, key personnel, capital/funding resources and past financial performance.  Al Hail the guarantor is the investment vehicle of a UAE royal family member used to invest in emerging growth areas, such as green technologies. Al Hail has significant holdings in UAE real estate, banking and technology companies like ATDC. Based on audited financial statements, Al Hail had approximately 360mm AED cash (USD 98mm) and 1,820mm AED (USD 500mm) as of 9/30/2021. ATDC is the primary obligor and Al Hail has a [majority] ownership in ATDC. For the years 2018, 2019, and 2020 ATDC has reported rises in annual net income of 4.8mm AED, 7.3mm AED, and 8.9mm AED respectively. This translates to a year-over-year growth rate of 53% in 2019 and 23% in 2020. As of December 31, 2020, ATDC had approximately 98mm AED in net assets. The Services Agreement generates cash and receivables collateral. The Services Agreement provides that ATDC will incur capex to improve the Al Walidia plants’ efficiency, and in exchange will receive cost savings which will be shared with the plant pursuant to the agreement. Please see the table below for estimates of the costs and revenues estimate for the remaining term of the Services Agreement.  The sufficiency of the Al Hail guarantee and the collateral to be pledged to the ADGM entity will be assessed by MakerDAO’s credit representatives with assistance from a third-party reputable firm as needed. Any third-party credit analysis will be paid for by ATDC.  Provide detailed summary of the proposed economic terms of the transaction, including, without limitation: commitment term, principal amount, interest rate, frequency of principal and interest payments, disbursement schedule, equity amount, funding ratios (equity/debt pro rata, equity first, etc.), collateral security, coverage ratios, currency (if not DAI) and other material terms. The quality of the proposed economic terms will be a consideration for the prioritization process.  ATDC has a 12-year agreement with EEHC to provide services in respect of the Al-Walidia power plant. ATDC has completed performance on the first four years of the 12-year term agreed upon by ATDC and EEHC. Principal: $35 Million (USD). The Note(s) will be funded using MakerDAO’s existing USDC holdings, or if such USDC is exhausted or, if MakerDAO prefers a DAI funding, then DAI will be minted to fund the investment in Note(s). In either case, USDC or DAI will be converted to USD using a third-party exchange. Stated Maturity: 5 years. Coupon: [2-2.5%] annualized, paid on a quarterly basis, together with a portion of the principal as set out in the amortization schedule to be agreed by ATDC and the RWA Core Unit.  Identify in reasonable detail the risks associated with this collateral application and the underlying asset(s) and proposed mitigants (if any). The risk summary should address, without limitation and to the extent relevant: market risks, commercial risks (e.g., diversification, credit, etc.), interest rate risks, legal and regulatory risks, general industry risks, competition, etc.  The main risks arising from ATDC’s financial instruments are currency risk and credit risk. Currency Risk ATDC manages currency risk through regular monitoring of the currency markets to determine appropriate action to minimize the exposure to the foreign currency risk. There are no significant exchange risks as substantially all the financial assets and liabilities are denominated in UAE Dirhams or US Dollars to which UAE Dirhams is pegged. Credit Risk Concentration of credit risk is due to 100% of ATDC’s trade receivables being from one customer. To offset this risk, ATD has received an unconditional guarantee from Al Hail.  Outline the applicant’s underwriting guidelines/policies, origination strategy (marketing, sales, channels), servicing strategy (charge-offs, collections), and historical asset performance.  The Al Walidia power plant project is ATDC’s pilot project and the obligations of EEHC are supported by the Egyptian government.  Outline the applicant’s risk monitoring and operations guidelines/policies (e.g., charge-offs, collection, recovery provisions, data collection and technology, etc).  ATDC manages currency risk through regular monitoring of the currency markets to determine appropriate action to minimize the exposure to the foreign currency risk. There are no significant exchange risks as substantially all the financial assets and liabilities are denominated in UAE Dirhams or US Dollars to which UAE Dirhams is pegged.  Describe the regulatory regime applicable to the underlying asset (if any) and the applicant’s legal and compliance program relating thereto.  A further review of the laws and regulations in the UAE, ADGM and Egypt as they relate to the issuance and purchase of the Notes will be conducted after the approval of this MIP6.  Identify any 3rd party persons likely to be relied upon by applicant to implement the transaction (legal, accounting, servicers, trustees, etc.).  Latham & Watkins will provide legal services, including drafting documents, performing necessary regulatory reviews, setting up a new entity in ADGM. Local Egyptian counsel will also be required to advise on any due diligence questions and advise on the security interest in the receivables under the Services Agreement. A third-party credit advisor acceptable to the RWA Core Unit may be engaged to perform further credit analysis on the Al Walidia Project and Al Hail. The content of this communication is for informational purposes only. You should not construe any information contained herein as legal, tax, investment, financial, or other advice. You should not rely on the information contained herein as a basis for making any business, legal or other decisions. Oasis Pro, as advisor, ATDC and Al Hail and each of its members, affiliates, officers, directors, owners, employees, agents, representatives, suppliers and service providers (collectively, the Proposers) cannot be held liable for any of the information contained in this communication. Nothing contained herein constitutes a solicitation, recommendation, endorsement, or offer by any of the Proposers to buy or sell any securities or other financial instruments in any jurisdiction. None of the Proposers makes any representation or warranty as to the completeness or accuracy of any information contained herein or that is sufficient for any purpose.

OPM, thanks for the thoughtful MIPs. Glad to see some interesting proposals at the intersection of EM x energy efficiency finally hit the forums. To set the stage, some questions:   As proposed, the yield is 1-1.5% with a .25% stability fee. What’s the mechanism here? 1.5% would be the all-in yield to the first-loss tranche of the debt (assuming ATDC is holding some risk retention) and Maker’s Senior position would yield .25%? Or is .25% a guaranteed fixed yield to the MakerDAO vault and the remainder is variable? If the latter is the case, variable based on what?   The gross yield on this debt is maximum 1.5% for five years. The yield on 1-year US Treasuries is 1.77%. The former has a guarantee from Al Hail, the latter the US government, the best credit on earth. What is the pricing rationale here?   What is OPMs understanding of the geopolitical risk present in Egypt at the moment? Due to ATDC’s agreement with EEHC (The “Egyptian Electricity Holding Company” is responsible for all power plants, transmission and distribution in the Arab Republic of Egypt), ATDC’s likelihood of being paid for services rendered is tied to EEHC solvency. The EEHC relies on Egyptian government subsidies. So MakerDAO credit risk is de facto Egyptian sovereign credit risk. Is there any reason to think that Egyptian sovereign debt has eroded or will continue to erode?   Greening: If I understand correctly, ATDC will make modifications to existing fuel turbines and unlock latent efficiencies. To me, people often ignore the practical value of modifying existing systems to reduce carbon emissions. It is much sexier to build renewables projects anew but such thinking is a luxury of decadent society. Can you confirm or direct me to a resource where I can read about the nature of the turbines MakerDAO will functionally be supporting? These are heavy fuel oil furnace + turbines, correct? Are these turbines mid-life or are they functionally at the end of their useful lives? Are we reviving an asset that should be retired and replaced with something greener?

@OasisProTeam Please, at your convenience, kick off the discourse with the community by answering my questions above. We’d like a vibrant discussion during the RFC phase prior to green-light. Getting more facts out into the open quickly will help A) determine whether we might engage with an external consultant and B)  assist RWF in generating a high-level triage for the benefit of voting token holders.
Is there any penalty or impact on the future cash flows in the event of a delay or inability to complete the project?

Also, is there any relationship between Al Hail Holding LLC and ATDC? And given this is not a bank or government guarantee, how can we get further comfort around the corporate guarantee from Al Hail which is a private company with no public ratings or track record? Thanks

Hi OPM Team, Just a few quick questions that should help the community understand the proposal a bit better:   Could you provide a sources and uses of funds table so that the community can understand how much of the funds are going to refinancing the existing loan, what is going to other Egyptian efficiency projects, the new solar thermal plant, fees, transaction costs, etc.? There is the possibility that this would not be viewed as a sustainability project if the majority of the funds are not being used to directly reducing fossil fuel consumption, and are viewed instead as extending the life of a fossil fuel burning plant.   I believe that the amounts quoted for what is available to Al Hail are on a consolidated basis. If so, are you able to provide a snapshot of what Al Hail has on a standalone basis to backstop the guarantee? Specifically, this would be its most recent cash position (not cash in subsidiaries), available credit facilities, etc. that would be used to support its obligations as guarantor.   You note that the AED:USD risk does not exist as AED are pegged to the dollar. However, is there a plan to mitigate the EGP:USD currency risk?

Thank you to @teej, @brian and others for the thoughtful comments. We are excited to be working on this opportunity with you and the Maker community. The following are in response to Teej’s questions and we are preparing responses to the other questions posted in consultation with ATDC.   As proposed, the yield is 1-1.5% with a .25% stability fee. What’s the mechanism here? 1.5% would be the all-in yield to the first-loss tranche of the debt (assuming ATDC is holding some risk retention) and Maker’s Senior position would yield .25%? Or is .25% a guaranteed fixed yield to the MakerDAO vault and the remainder is variable? If the latter is the case, variable based on what?   The original rate proposed in brackets in the MIP did not reflect recent USD interest rate increases. However, in light of the current environment, we propose a range of 2-2.5% for these secured, guaranteed notes which will represent senior obligations of both ATDC and Al Hail.   The gross yield on this debt is maximum 1.5% for five years. The yield on 1-year US Treasuries is 1.77%. The former has a guarantee from Al Hail, the latter the US government, the best credit on earth. What is the pricing rationale here?   As mentioned above, we are revising the interest rate proposed to 2-2.5%. Al Hail, the guarantor of the notes, is the investment vehicle of a UAE royal family member. Al Hail represents his personal investments in emerging growth areas, such as green technology. As mentioned in the MIP, the guarantee provided will be an unconditional guarantee which will cover all of ATDC’s payment obligations under the notes.   What is OPMs understanding of the geopolitical risk present in Egypt at the moment? Due to ATDC’s agreement with EEHC (The “Egyptian Electricity Holding Company” is responsible for all power plants, transmission and distribution in the Arab Republic of Egypt), ATDC’s likelihood of being paid for services rendered is tied to EEHC solvency. The EEHC relies on Egyptian government subsidies. So MakerDAO credit risk is de facto Egyptian sovereign credit risk. Is there any reason to think that Egyptian sovereign debt has eroded or will continue to erode?   Since its formation in 1976, EEHC has not defaulted on any of its commitments. Currently, international development organizations, such as the German KFW and the World Bank are funding EEHC’s expansion. Due to the reduction in government subsidies, the prices for electricity have increased and are expected to continue to increase until 2025 (when the subsidies end). For further reference, please find a Fitch ratings summary for Egypt. https://www.fitchratings.com/research/sovereigns/fitch-affirms-egypt-at-b-outlook-stable-20-10-2021 Also, IRENA anticipates growth in the Egyptian economy, as illustrated in the chart below:  ATDC Question 3 Table936×764 297 KB    Greening: If I understand correctly, ATDC will make modifications to existing fuel turbines and unlock latent efficiencies. To me, people often ignore the practical value of modifying existing systems to reduce carbon emissions. It is much sexier to build renewables projects anew but such thinking is a luxury of decadent society. Can you confirm or direct me to a resource where I can read about the nature of the turbines MakerDAO will functionally be supporting? These are heavy fuel oil furnace + turbines, correct? Are these turbines mid-life or are they functionally at the end of their useful lives? Are we reviving an asset that should be retired and replaced with something greener?   Teej, you are correct. The Egyptian power plant has two 300 MWe boilers, each producing (1000 tons/hr) steam at high pressure (167 Bar) and high temperature (540C). The generated steam expands in two 300MWe steam turbines to generate electricity. To maintain the high performance of the equipment, ATDC has dedicated a full-time technical team placed in the plant for the duration of the contract with EEHC. This dedicated team closely monitors the units on a daily basis and takes necessary preventive measures to maximize the reduction in fuel consumption, which in turn results in lower carbon emissions. The plant’s book value will be realized by 2036. ATDC’s contract ends in 2029. Also, it is noteworthy to mention that the plant has been central to stabilizing Egypt’s power grid and connecting the north with the south of Egypt. Replacing the fossil-based plants by intermittent renewables plants in that region in the foreseeable future is not feasible for the stability of the grid.

OasisProTeam:  As proposed, the yield is 1-1.5% with a .25% stability fee. What’s the mechanism here? 1.5% would be the all-in yield to the first-loss tranche of the debt (assuming ATDC is holding some risk retention) and Maker’s Senior position would yield .25%? Or is .25% a guaranteed fixed yield to the MakerDAO vault and the remainder is variable? If the latter is the case, variable based on what?   Can you please explain the proposed waterfall mechanism? i.e. a proposed SF of .25% but an all-in yield to MakerDAO of 1-1.5% (2.5% if proposal changes as per recent OPM comms).     OasisProTeam:  The original rate proposed in brackets in the MIP did not reflect recent USD interest rate increases. However, in light of the current environment, we propose a range of 2-2.5% for these secured, guaranteed notes which will represent senior obligations of both ATDC and Al Hail.   The point is well-taken, though it does worry me a bit that the initial proposal was 1-1.5%. Though short-term US treasury rates have risen significantly over the past couple months, they’ve been rising more or less for the last six months, so the financial world has long since adjusted. The two-year has been above 1.5% for two months. The five-year, our risk free rate of like-kind duration for the ATDC proposed transaction, has been above 1.5% since January. The initial proposal feels like a low-ball that wouldn’t get done on the open market. Could be wrong, will leave it to the MakerDAO hive mind to sort it. A less empirical, more intuitive take: Maybe the guarantee from Al Hail excites other senior lenders, but seems like a messy dynamic that wouldn’t benefit MakerDAO as it would those with local knowledge of gulf politics, finance, and general norms. The prospect of MakerDAO forcing compliance of a credit guarantee by the UAE Royal Family in a gulf court is almost laughable to consider. I could be deeply off-base here. As you’ve mentioned, ATDC would cover third-party credit analysis. This brings some comfort, but it suffers from incentive design as an “issuer pays” model.     beedubs:  You note that the AED:USD risk does not exist as AED are pegged to the dollar. However, is there a plan to mitigate the EGP:USD currency risk?   I was curious about this as well. 10.5% EGP inflation as of March. Not much higher than USD I suppose lol     OasisProTeam:  Since its formation in 1976, EEHC has not defaulted on any of its commitments. Currently, international development organizations, such as the German KFW and the World Bank are funding EEHC’s expansion. Due to the reduction in government subsidies, the prices for electricity have increased and are expected to continue to increase until 2025 (when the subsidies end). For further reference, please find a Fitch ratings summary for Egypt.   Good data point. Where can it be independently verified? Though past performance is not indicative of future performance, it’s the best predictor we’ve got. If performance was steady through the Arab Spring, that says something. With that said, what worries me is the unique salvo of macro events converging on the Egyptian government and, by extension, EEHC, at the moment. As many macro-savvy community members are aware, the Egyptian government subsidizes energy and foodstuffs, an example of which is wheat, for the benefit of its citizens. Since 1989, subsidized bakeries have provided 20 loaves of bread for one Egyptian Pound. Because Egypt imports 86% of its wheat from Ukraine/Russia, its government will have to either work the higher commodity prices into the budget (increase the fiscal deficit) or renege on this 30-year promise. Anwar Sadat attempted to remove bread subsidies in 1977, only to change tack when violent riots started. The Arab Spring was also, in some part, catalyzed by high food prices. The sovereign budget accounts for bread prices of $255 per tonne; prices on futures markets are near $400 per tonne. The adjustment to the federal budget will be equivalent to 0.3% of GDP. This article by The Economist summarizes the issue nicely. As of a Reuters article dated 3/8/2022, EGP-denominated government bonds have been decimated, trading in the 63-66 cent range, an all-time low. Investors are demanding a 980 bps spread over like-duration US treasuries, an all-time high. For those unfamiliar, a spread is the increase yield beyond a “risk-free rate” that an investor demands for holding an asset. Spreads blow out as the perceived risk of holding an asset increases. Finally, credit default swaps on Egyptian sovereign debt are at all time highs. CDS on five-year Egyptian sovereign debt. As per this chart which tracks Egyptian CDS prices,, it appears these fundamentals have since improved. I am not a macro expert but this does strike me as a uniquely bad time to be making five year bets, for which we are paid 1-2.5% on a country with a non-trivial chance of popular revolt. We could just buy a five-year treasury and call it a day.     OasisProTeam:  The plant’s book value will be realized by 2036. ATDC’s contract ends in 2029.   So we are potentially funding through 2027, so we need to think about our take-out financing as of 2026. We need to hope that either A) the party that refinances our loan is comfortable with three years remaining on the contract term or B) the contract gets renewed/extended over the course of our loan. So, in other words, more risk. @christiancdpetersen Please mansplain to me if I am oversimplifying. @Recognized-Delegates Please add some fodder, especially if you’ve familiarity with energy, Egypt, or the Middle East.
Where would this deal price in the real world currently? Given the US 5 Yr Treasury is at about 2.7%, it seems likely well north of 3%?

teej:  @Recognized-Delegates Please add some fodder, especially if you’ve familiarity with energy, Egypt, or the Middle East.   Well, not much of an expert on the region–but as you know hard financial assets are a key commodity in a high inflationary environment. And unfortunately Oil will continue to be the leading asset class of this region, we have to think with the current inflationary environment, this region will pull more Oil investments into it. I was recently reading about a region in Western Australia, called Pilbara. It’s a huge, dry region known for its “red earth” and mineral deposits. It is also a biodiversity “hotspot.”  Supposedly the wind almost always blows and the sun shines a lot. Hence, it’s a huge renewable energy source, that has a current proposal (can’t remember by who) that will develop the largest power plant in the world to supply renewable energy to Asia. So, where else besides Pilabara (AU) can you find a hot, dry place with constant winds and lots of sunshine? The Middle East. And as I mentioned earlier, this region supplies a lot of energy via Oil tankers, specially to Asia. Can Egypt/Middle East duplicate the Pilbara concept and replace oil and gas with something like, carbon free hydrogen? That remains to be seen. And it will need some serious investments. Again, not knowledgeable enough to produce a concrete view–only an educated guess. It is also why the Delegates have asked for Help via the reformed greenlight process with RWAs–which includes the opinions and views of the RWF CU, LOVE, Legal, and CES. However, we do have a few folks/friends that are more informed with regards to the region, and we’ll try to dig in for more details as possible. Usually these folks always question the low rates that Maker offers to lenders, for high-risk loans. All-in-all we are interested in continuing to follow the due-dilly process that you are currently providing to MKR token owners and Delegates, and for taking time to do such, we say Thank You! Much appreciated Teej.

The incubating Legal and Transactional Services core unit is pleased to provide the following questions/observations to this MIP## (MIP6?). Please note that these are high level questions/observations based on the information provided to date. A more comprehensive diligence and analysis of the overall transaction, contracts, cash-flow, etc. is required to form a complete picture and form an educated opinion.   As noted elsewhere, we will need to diligence the credit profile of Al-Hail.   We assume that the guarantee will be a standard English law guarantee with customary waivers of defenses etc.   We will want to ensure that Al Hail can be sued and that any claims against Al Hail and ADT are enforceable in UAE.   To confirm if the service fees payable by EEHC are denominated in USD. ATDC is working on developing technologies that will not only apply to conventional fossil fuels but also to green fuels. Our plan dictates to rollout the products first using conventional fuels for energy generation. This is followed by using the same technologies to utilize green fuels such as hydrogen and green ammonia. A case in point, our gas turbine combustor technology is being funded at a bench scale level by the US Department Of Energy (DOE) to develop the combustion system using green ammonia as a fuel. As a result of our success in phase I, DOE awarded us phase II. To this effect, a major part of the loan will be allocated to complete the development and the rollout of the new technologies and get them ready for commercial use.  Once the green fuels are commercially feasible, ATDC will be in a leading position to apply its new technologies using the green fuels. Please find below a short summary for each item of the use of funds areas.   Efficiency improvement; This constitutes the application of further conventional solutions in the plant with the objective of increasing further the efficiency in the plant especially at part load levels.   Solar thermal technology; In power plants, not all generated steam is utilized to generate electricity. A sizable portion of the steam is used to satisfy some consumers in the plant. ATDC identified the need to develop a solution that would not require firing fossil fuel to generate the steam. This will be accomplished by the solar thermal system. The latter will generate the required steam from sun rays and as a result reduce the fossil fuel consumption and in turn the carbon emissions. The company intends to build a plant that will produce the solar thermal petals and spread their use in the industrial and power generation markets.   Gas turbines require air filtration systems to remove dust particles from the air before entering the compressor of the gas turbine. ATDC identified the need to develop a high efficiency filtration system that will help the gas turbines maintain their efficiency. To this effect, the company will be building up a high efficiency gas turbine filtration factory to produce these filters.   As part of the work ATDC done in Walidia power plant in Egypt is to develop a strategy for improving the combustion efficiency in the boilers. It was recognized that if the combustion efficiency is poor the carbon emissions are very high. To this effect, ATDC developed a new High Efficiency Advanced Telescopic (HEAT) burner system that improves significantly the combustion efficiency in boilers and as such reduce the carbon emission. The funds allocated for this project is to complete the development and apply the new technology in new energy improvement projects in large steam boilers whether for power generation or for industrial applications.   ATDC recognized that the gas turbine applications market is growing and will continue to grow. The company developed a new disruptive combustion technology (T-fired combustion technology) that will enhance the performance of the gas turbines while at the same reduce pollutants emissions from the turbines. The funds allocated will be demonstrate the technology at a 16 MW level prior to its application at various scale levels.    PastedGraphic-21824×1076 94.3 KB

RWF is comfortable issuing the following for the benefit of MakerDAO token holders who may participate in the active green-light poll. Please keep in mind that this only my opinion. I have sought to take: A) The facts presented in the initial MIP-6, the forum discussion, and the onboarding call B) My understanding of how the world works C) What I understand the priorities of the protocol to be and combine them into a coherent recommendation. Token holders should always DYOR— surely I’ll have mischaracterized some things. Recommendation: No greenlight. As structured, this opportunity appears to provide poor risk-adjusted return to the protocol. The proposed return is below the risk-free rate (US treasuries) of similar duration. The threat of geopolitical tail-risk and a convoluted recovery process is non-trivial. Putting the specifics around terms aside, I further believe that there is a fundamental mismatch between the nature of this collateral and the needs of MakerDAO over the long-term. This is as much if not more a matter of MakerDAO idiosyncrasy than it is a criticism of the proposed assets. For RWAs to be profitable and provide value to token holders, MakerDAO should be focusing on wholesale-esc relationships that scale. I.e. build a commercial/legal/technical structure once, underwrite the underwriter, and drip additional funding to them as the vault seasons and the underwriter performs. MakerDAO ought not to be a jack of all trades and master of none. It wants to empower specialist lenders to execute in their niches, not to build out a bloated and ineffective credit underwriting department. The asset, esoteric, energy-related, and foreign, will be VERY complicated to diligence and because it is a one-off project ($35MM), as opposed to a more programmatic arrangement with a manager, will be difficult to scale.   Opportunities:     Diversification/Social: Emerging market exposure.      Greening: Potential reduction of fossil fuels reliance in Egypt.      Safe-ish: De-Facto Egyptian sovereign debt, also guaranteed by UAE royals.      Infrastructure: Establish a lending practice in Africa/Middle East      Platform: Opportunity to partner with a new arranger, Oasis Pro Markets. OPM may offer an appealing tokenization solution for real world assets and is one of a few entities to obtain an Alternative Trading System (ATS) license. This allows its subscribers to trade blockchain securities.      Threats:     Sharpe Ratio: The return on the proposed five-year note is below that of a two-year US treasury, one of the safest assets on earth. The assets pose more risk, as proposed, than MakerDAO is compensated for.      Geopolitical Risk: Egyptian government debt is experiencing contemporary (and maybe temporary) deterioration. Egypt is one of three countries that the IMF is currently focused on.      Supply Chain Tail Risk: Ukraine War has strained Egypt’s subsidization policy and presents risk of social dissent due to increasing wheat, fertilizer, and energy prices.      Greening risk: Though supporting more efficient use of fossil fuels (and thus reduction in GHG) is definitely net good, MakerDAO dollars are ultimately funding the continued operation of heavy fuel oil boilers + turbines. I will leave it to token holders to guage this one.      Scaling Risk: opportunity is a one-off and does not have the legs to scale. (No infrastructural leverage)      OPM will be a great future partner for MakerDAO, but it is not through this proposed formulation that the most productive version of that partnership is born.

This post has been written by myself as prospective Facilitator of the Lending Oversight Core Unit (LOVE-001) Thank you for your post @teej. Although you specify that the post outlines your own personal opinion on the MIP, I am assuming that this has been shared by @williamr as Facilitator of RWF-001 and is the best representation of the Core Unit’s opinion. I believe the post gives token holders the most transparent view on the collateral, including opportunities and threats that a greenlight vote would carry. I have witnessed the interactions between RWF-001 and the Proponent (@OasisProTeam) and I can attest that the process has been transparent, fair, professional, and highly engaged by both parties. As customary, the decision remains with the token holders. On a purely financial standpoint, LOVE’s recommendation would be to vote against greenlighting the collateral. In addition, I believe that the ad hoc nature of the deal - vs. a more programmatic relationship that can be progressively scaled by MakerDAO - would not be the most efficient use of the DAO’s resources given the complex negotiations that any real-world deal entails. However, given the current inception phase of Maker’s real-world asset program, it is with each token holder to weigh non-financial benefits (e.g. publicity, impact, strategic relationships with borrowers and intermediaries, etc.) against the threats outlined by TeeJ in the post above. RWF-001 should provide the best possible support to the counterparty along the collateral onboarding process in case the community decides to vote in favour. OPM appreciates all the thoughtful comments that have been submitted on our first two MIPs. OPM’s approach to presenting the ATDC transaction, as well as India Power, is to offer a financing opportunity that provides the Maker community with green energy, emerging markets real-world assets, backed by guarantees and a listing venue for the securities for price discovery. This financing is structured as notes to create potential liquidity and transparent valuation to the Maker community through the creation of secondary market on the OPM ATS. ATDC is flexible on the interest rate for the notes. In a traditional finance transaction, rates are set closer to the actual funding. If the community is prioritizing yield over obtaining green, emerging markets assets, then the interest rate discussion should happen closer to the actual funding, as is the case in traditional finance. To address some of the recent questions and commentary, below are a few salient points from the ATDC MIP6 and the posted responses to questions above:   While this MIP6 is for a $35mm financing, the opportunity to fund additional green projects in Egypt and other countries in the Middle East could be as much as $500mm - $1bn.   The risk to Egypt is mitigated by a pledged cash account in ADGM and the guarantee of Al Hail Holding, the investment company of a member of the royal family that had $500 million equivalent of AED (which is pegged to the U.S. dollar)   Item 14 of the MIP6 details the proposed legal structure and Christian’s comments highlight the work that we need to do if this MIP6 is approved.  That process has begun and we had a call with UAE counsel to discuss the enforceability of the guarantee against Al Hail and there is a process to enforce against a UAE entity.   While ATDC’s projects may appear initially to support a fossil fuel plant, they are reducing carbon emissions while moving toward sustainable forms of energy. Egypt is committed to installing solar power plants in the upcoming years. ATDC produced the following chart showing the progression from fossil fuel plants to green energy sources.    PastedGraphic-21824×1076 94.3 KB   This MIP6 was submitted by Oasis Pro, solely as an advisor to ATDC. Oasis Pro will not receive any of the proceeds of the funding and is not a party to the transaction – this transaction benefits the Maker community and ATDC. Oasis Pro as advisor and as a provider of a secondary trading venue would receive customary investment banking advisory fees and trading commissions. It is unclear how the ownership of Oasis Pro relates to this transaction.
Everyone should take note – this CU has NOT been voted in yet.

For the benefit of the Community of MKR tokenholders and delegates, I’d like to weight in on process and aspects of the recommendation on “greenlight” discussed here. First of all, as a CU we have deep respect for counterparties like @OasisProTeam that engage teams like ours in a professional and open manner from the start. I believe the relationship is of mutual professional treatment and has been like that since its inception. Second, on process which relates to points covered by fellow professionals @luca_pro and the rest of the RWF team:  Team members are assigned to diligence MIP6 applications at the different stages of the process: pre-greenlight and post-greenlight poll. During pre-greenlight the work is primarily on process guidance to counterparties (see approved MIP67). During pre-greenlight, team members are exposed to materials and documentation provided by the counterparty which allows team members to gain insights into the materiality of the deal but also on early identification of possible risks in its delivery, if/when greenlit. Where no industry expertise exists in the core CU to professionally assess a deal, grantees with the required industry experience are engaged to apply their experience in the assessment. Core team members are, in that capacity, “buddied up” with experts to summarise their outputs. This was the case in this OPM pre-greenlight review. Team members present and discuss their preliminary views (pre-greenlight) on a particular deal with other team members, including myself, as facilitator of the RWF-01 CU. They gather their inputs and then incorporate any feedback into reviews, if applicable. Team members publish that view to the Community of MKR tokenholders and delegates for the sake of information/opinion only, given they had the time to review/analyse the deal with some level of depth prior to its execution.  Team members fully recognise that, at the end of the day, they are not decision-makers. They are engaged by MKR tokenholders as expert contractors to emit a professional view/opinion, whether it is from a credit or legal perspective, on a deal, including its risk adjusted returns and other risks.  But MKR tokenholders are the only eventual decision-makers. This entails MKR tokenholders have every possible right to override any credit recommendation, be it positive or negative, if they deem appropriate, strategic or for any other intrinsic reasons to fit the direction they want the protocol to move towards.  This last point is important. Given expert/experienced teams are engaged to professionally assess and work with counterparties. If the owners of the protocol, i.e. MKR tokenholders, make the decision to override a recommendation, teams are still engaged to assist in the facilitation of its execution in the same professional manner they do DD along with other collateral onboarding teams (CES, Growth, incubating LTS). However, teams are also engaged as consultants to explicitly present their professional opinion on the difficulties/challenges that might be encountered in the execution of that duty of onboarding a collateral/deal, if/when greenlit. The challenges shall be of credit, legal or technological nature. I trust this provides some light into the process, as requested by @luca_pro. Once again, I’d like to respectfully thank @teej and @beedubs for having had a first glance at the deal details and for providing constructive feedback to the @OasisProTeam team to this point. Kind regards, William

I toned down my hyperbole a bit for the sake of discussion but I want to make my position crystal clear. My concern is not that the RWA group gives a “no” recommendation or makes suggestions on how a MIP can be improved. That’s the job of an advisor. As the inordinate delays drag on, people get bored and distracted or excited by the latest shiny collateral type and momentum dies, which seems like the result the RWA team intends. And isn’t saying “no” at the greenlight stage before something has even passed and been sent to the CUs for analysis the definition of gatekeeping? This question is actually critical. We aren’t onboarding collateral in a vacuum. Each new proposal should be considered with regard to the “balance of power”. i.e. How picky can we be and still grow? And the answer is very picky. Two reasons:  After HVB and SocGen, Maker has leveled up. We’ve received myriad inquiries over the last month from international real estate firms, credit funds, and banks. Anchorage is ready to go. Things have fundamentally changed. As TradFi rates rise and liquidity is pulled from capital markets, Maker’s low cost of capital becomes very appealing to asset managers.  Because we continue to do RWAs the right way, we’ve now earned the right to be cynical in what we onboard. As such, let’s continue along that path: each deal should be better than the last.
